docs.abstract: Speaking at a companywide meeting, Mark Parker signaled there might be more managerial moves in the wake of allegations of misconduct and bias against women.
docs.snippet: Speaking at a companywide meeting, Mark Parker signaled there might be more managerial moves in the wake of allegations of misconduct and bias against women.
docs.lead_paragraph: The chief executive of Nike told employees that departures related to workplace behavior will be completed in the coming days, a move that sought to reassure a work force jolted by allegations of misconduct and discrimination against women and gain closure on one of the most turbulent periods in the company’s history.

headline.main: Nike’s C.E.O. Vows Changes After Claims of Workplace Harassment and Bias
headline.print_headline: Nike’s Chief Vows Changes After Claims of Workplace Harassment and Bias

byline.original: By Kevin Draper and Julie Creswell

docs.abstract: After representing Jimi Hendrix, Sly Stone and other music stars, he challenged The Village Voice, covering Lower Manhattan in a grittier era.
docs.snippet: After representing Jimi Hendrix, Sly Stone and other music stars, he challenged The Village Voice, covering Lower Manhattan in a grittier era.
docs.lead_paragraph: Michael Goldstein, a music publicist who made a fortune turning vinyl records into gold before starting The SoHo Weekly News, a spirited newspaper that over a nine-year run was bent on silencing its rival The Village Voice, died on May 19 at his home in Manhattan. He was 79.

headline.main: Michael Goldstein, Publicist Who Started SoHo Weekly News, Dies at 79
headline.print_headline: Michael Goldstein, Publicist Who Founded SoHo Weekly News, Dies at 79

docs.abstract: Starbucks is under fire for temporarily shutting 8,000 stores on Tuesday to train employees about bias. The effort won’t solve the problem, but it’s a good start.
docs.snippet: Starbucks is under fire for temporarily shutting 8,000 stores on Tuesday to train employees about bias. The effort won’t solve the problem, but it’s a good start.
docs.lead_paragraph: Starbucks will temporarily shut 8,000 stores for four hours Tuesday afternoon to conduct racial bias training for its employees. It follows an incident in Philadelphia last month in which two black men were arrested simply for waiting in a store.

headline.main: Why Starbucks’s Bias Training, Despite Skepticism, Is an Important Start
headline.print_headline: Bias Session At Starbucks Is a First Step

docs.abstract: Last year, Blackstone announced a $40 billion infrastructure fund with a huge commitment from the Saudis. It hasn’t come together as planned.
docs.snippet: Last year, Blackstone announced a $40 billion infrastructure fund with a huge commitment from the Saudis. It hasn’t come together as planned.
docs.lead_paragraph: Last May, the private equity firm Blackstone announced that it was creating a $40 billion fund that would invest in infrastructure projects in the United States. The fund’s largest backer was the government of Saudi Arabia, which agreed to kick in half the cash.

headline.main: Massive United States-Saudi Infrastructure Fund Struggles to Get Going
headline.print_headline: Infrastructure Fund Is Slow To Equal Hype

byline.original: By Kate Kelly and Andrew Ross Sorkin

docs.abstract: The last year gave us some whopping deals, including Amazon.com’s acquisition of Whole Foods, that will shape the business landscape in 2018.
docs.snippet: The last year gave us some whopping deals, including Amazon.com’s acquisition of Whole Foods, that will shape the business landscape in 2018.

headline.main: Toasts to the Deals (and Other Winners) of 2017
headline.print_headline: Raise a Glass To the Deals Of the Year

docs.abstract: As Corporate America espouses “social responsibility,” the financial industry could help limit sales of assault weapons, our columnist writes.
docs.snippet: As Corporate America espouses “social responsibility,” the financial industry could help limit sales of assault weapons, our columnist writes.
docs.lead_paragraph: For the past year, chief executives have often talked about the new sense of moral responsibility that corporations have to help their communities and confront social challenges even when Washington won’t.

headline.main: How Banks Could Control Gun Sales if Washington Won’t
headline.print_headline: Congress Fails To Curb Guns. Could Banks?

docs.abstract: Investment firms like Larry Fink’s BlackRock have preached social responsibility. With guns, they can use their influence to achieve it.
docs.snippet: Investment firms like Larry Fink’s BlackRock have preached social responsibility. With guns, they can use their influence to achieve it.
docs.lead_paragraph: Over the past several weeks, there has been a lot of talk about investors ridding themselves of their shares in gun manufacturers and retailers after the school shooting in Parkland, Fla. A number of public pension funds, like those in the state of Connecticut, have discussed the prospect of selling their shares.

headline.main: Big Investors Have Clout. They Can Use It With Gun Makers.

docs.abstract: The internet giant has plenty of problems to fix. Andrew Ross Sorkin thinks explaining why particular ads are presented to users would be a good start.
docs.snippet: The internet giant has plenty of problems to fix. Andrew Ross Sorkin thinks explaining why particular ads are presented to users would be a good start.
docs.lead_paragraph: “One of our biggest responsibilities is to protect data.”

headline.main: Facebook Should Consider a ‘Why Me?’ Button
headline.print_headline: A Button Facebook Could Use: ‘Why Me?’

docs.abstract: New York’s attorney general has sued the Weinstein Company, delaying a sale, to ensure that victims of abuse are compensated. Will his tactic backfire?
docs.snippet: New York’s attorney general has sued the Weinstein Company, delaying a sale, to ensure that victims of abuse are compensated. Will his tactic backfire?
docs.lead_paragraph: It seems like a noble pursuit: Eric T. Schneiderman, New York’s attorney general, filed a lawsuit over the weekend against the Weinstein Company over the “toxic” environment it created that allowed its co-founder Harvey Weinstein to harass and abuse dozens of women.

headline.main: Does a Lawsuit Now Help the Weinstein Victims?
headline.print_headline: Blocking Sale Could Hurt The Victims Of Weinstein

docs.abstract: The legislation, approved by the House, would have put employees of tribal enterprises like casinos outside the scope of federal labor law.
docs.snippet: The legislation, approved by the House, would have put employees of tribal enterprises like casinos outside the scope of federal labor law.
docs.lead_paragraph: Organized labor managed an increasingly rare feat on Monday — a political victory — when its allies turned back a Senate measure aimed at rolling back labor rights on tribal lands.

headline.main: Senate Bill to Curtail Labor Rights on Tribal Land Falls Short
headline.print_headline: Bill to Curtail Labor Rights On Tribal Land Falls Short

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: AMERICAN FEDERATION OF LABOR-CONGRESS OF INDUSTRIAL ORGANIZATIONS
